This recipe also produces 1 mol of water, but this is ignored at the moment.  This recipe actually produces a mixture of 2-nitrochlorobenzene (1/3 of mass) and 4-nitrochlorobenzene (2/3 of mass), but the former is discarded as it currently has no use.

This recipe also produces 1 mol of water as a byproduct, but this is ignored at the moment.

This recipe actually features 3 steps.  1: bornyl chloride is combined with aniline to produce N-isobornyl aniline.  2: N-isobornyl aniline is heated with sulfur to produce isobornyl anil.  3. Isobornyl anil is hydrolyzed with aqueous nitric acid or hydrochloric acid to get camphor. They are integrated into a single recipe right now because no data is available on the physical properties of N-isobornyl aniline and isobornyl anil that would be needed to have them as distinct items.
This recipe also produces 1 mol of sodium sulfite (currently useless) and 1 mol of water as byproduct, but those are ignored at the moment.
